Hi, I’m really new to Android, and I’m currently trying to implement a settings page. I’ve been reading documentation, but it still is pretty confusing because I still don’t really understand Android event listeners that well. I was wondering if anyone can help me with my code and figure out why my Settings aren’t working.

this is my current onSharedPreferenceChanged code. but the first part, the switch KEY_PREF_DEMO_MODE, is not even working, and none of the other ones are working either in terms of showing up correctly on the screen after I change it (the summary)
it probably has something to do with the OnSharedPreferenceChangeListener
i have no idea where to define it/where to put it
<@U1HLGB8AE>: you're sure that code is being called? i mean, you registered the listener to your sharedpreferences, and when you change one in the UI, that callback is being triggered?
are you using PreferenceActivity or PreferenceFragment? or something else?
so i have this in my onCreate in my larger SettingsActivity.java
but i have a SettingsFragment in my SettingsActivity because I know that’s how Android wants you to implement it or whatever
should i be putting it in the onCreate of the Fragment? I’m so confused lol
yep, but the callback won't be triggered unless a preference changes from `prefs`
I barely understand fragments too
FWIW I don't remember the last time I've gotten `OnSharedPreferenceChangeListener` working
lol
how do you do this then :’(
even after accounting for the fact that it's held as a weak reference
<@U1HLGB8AE>: I use RxJava myself
PreferenceActivity/Fragment is kinda dumb, yeah i've had trouble before
<@U0546QERR>: isn’t that solved from the onSharedPreferenceChanged thingy?
i just copied and pasted that code ^ from a StackOverflow answer
and i know that onSharedPreferenceChanged for the stackoverflow answer is defined inside, but i have mine defined outside, so I don’t know what to do
<@U053LEHJN>: what’s RxJava?
<@U1HLGB8AE>: honestly, I'd avoid the listener and instead write some Preferences interface and implement that for your app to use
then in your implementation you can manually notify observers of preference updates
via RxJava or otherwise
<@U1HLGB8AE>: <http://reactivex.io/>, but it's probably beyond the scope of what you're trying to do for now
i thought about writing some preferences framework this weekend because i was frustrated with android's implementation
<@U053LEHJN>: how do I write some Preferences interface?
but there's a lot of different types of preferences and i didn't feel like implementing all of the dialogs and stuff
tbh i just need one switch
like the other stuff can be disregarded

okay `private SharedPreferences prefs = PreferenceManager.getDefaultSharedPreferences(getActivity());` won't work declared straight as a field, `getActivity()` won't resolve until `onAttach` (or `onCreate`)
so shift that assignment into onCreate

makes sense

<@U1LJRDN0K>: ya, I find it to be good/great. Some other people here probably use it too.

<@U1LJRDN0K>: it outperforms SQLite afaik, best performer on the block
<@U061HDV96>: granted that isn’t a very high bar =P
<@U055GGAHS>: that is true
i thought realm was just really fast in specific operations
the general problem with storage on mobile is how poorly the physical storage can perform specially in regards to it being highly variable if background work is also occurring
I've gone back to regular sql (with the help of StorIO), going to see how that goes
<@U04U5KS3Z>: I would imagine realm is regarded as fast in high read environments as it automatically performs memory caching so your data is often coming from memory
<@U04U5KS3Z>: you can use SQLDelight with StorIO btw
interesting. only had a brief look at Brite/Delight, but i'll keep that in mind
thanks, this discussion helps me a lot
<@U1LJRDN0K>: <@U091EBYSU> is the developer of StorIO btw
i use StorIO <@U061HDV96>
<@U04U5KS3Z>: realm is really fast because they don’t have locks and are partially in-memory
<@U0548MM6B>: and benchmarks measure lazy queries without inflation of model objects (that was true when I looked at them some time in past)
keep in mind that Realm makes you do things like extend a base class for your models. Which I think is kind of gross...

<@U1LRL7HF1|rcunning> has joined the channel

hello,
I'm trying to find a proper (architecture-wise) way to implement a Navigation Drawer, but 9 tutorials out of 10 seem to point to a very simplistic and non-abstract one.
I'll expand:
I think that instead of implementing the Drawer inside an activity, Drawer being "Material"-istically speaking above the other elements, it should be some sort of container or controller that sits hierarchically above all other views and controls them from its menu, which should only be really loaded once instead of loaded and rendered anew in each activity.

It seems to me like most implementations are really just code duplication, forcing you to initialize the Drawer in each activity separately, when in fact the good implementation should be some super-activity containing the navigation. and as for the app's activities, naturally it seems like they should be fragments.

and this is where I'm in need of help. because turning all the app's activities to fragments managed by the navigation drawer seems first like the proper way to go for it, but then.... it's also a bad idea considering that I'd be avoiding the proper android lifecycle of activities now that they've turned fragments.

I reckon, and perhaps wrongly so(?), that in order to have this "proper" implementation of NavigationDrawerController which exhibits activities as fragments, I'd also have to be responsible to manage the fragments' lifecycle and intents in a very rigorous manner, which might cause me trouble further down the line... just like other implementations that ignore or alter good practices of android's activity lifecycle.
so in a way, my question would be: *what is the best practice for a NavDrawer implementation that doesn't resort to code duplication (and doesn't mess with the proper activity lifecycle)?*
We have a `BaseActivity` that every other activity extends from which handles the drawer.
our current app uses inheritance with drawer logic built in. Not saying it’s the best idea (it’s not), and we’re migrating to a simpler nav soon.
there are some open source single activity frameworks out there
like scoop etc
